So yes, we have seen the review. We have seen the audit.

headline: Wisconsin Energy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So you guys are in a great position to answer some of these -- well, I'm not going to ask you to go all overall, but I mean just this idea that the budget has ballooned according to some of the filings that they're attributing to this program and that it'
componenttext: So you guys are in a great position to answer some of these -- well, I'm not going to ask you to go all overall, but I mean just this idea that the budget has ballooned according to some of the filings that they're attributing to this program and that it's sort of behind schedule and way over budget, I guess, is basically sort of what we're hearing. When you look at it, knowing what you know about, obviously, gas utility work and what have you, you guys feel comfortable that this is the program that can be managed and completed in a commercially effective way. Is that a good way to put it? Or -- do you follow me?

headline: Wisconsin Energy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, let me answer it this way. There are a lot of moving pieces in terms of what the eventual costs might be. But do we believe based on what we've seen? That, a, the work is needed, and, b, it can be done professionally and at long-term cost effective
componenttext:
Well, let me answer it this way. There are a lot of moving pieces in terms of what the eventual costs might be. But do we believe based on what we've seen? That, a, the work is needed, and, b, it can be done professionally and at long-term cost effective way? Yes. But at this point, I don't think it's appropriate for us to comment on what the exact right budget numbers should be. But as we look at the recommendations from the Liberty audit, I mean, the recommendations, frankly, make a great deal of sense. There's nothing in the Liberty audit that I have seen that is troublesome from the standpoint of can we effectively manage the program? I'm confident we can. 
All right, ladies and gentlemen, well, I think that concludes our conference call for today. We really appreciate you participating. If you have any other questions, the famous Colleen Henderson is available in our Investor Relations office at (414) 221-2592.
Thanks, again, everybody. Have a great day.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for waiting and welcome to WEC Energy Group's Conference Call to Review the 2015 Second Quarter results. This call is being recorded for rebroadcast, and all participants are in a listen-only mode at this ti
componenttext:
Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for waiting and welcome to WEC Energy Group's Conference Call to Review the 2015 Second Quarter results. This call is being recorded for rebroadcast, and all participants are in a listen-only mode at this time. Before the conference call begins, I would read the forward-looking language. All statements in this presentation, other than historical facts, are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, which are subject to change at any time. Such statements are based on management's expectations at the time they are made. In addition to the assumptions and other factors referred to in connection with the statements, factors described in WEC Energy Group's and Integrys Holdings latest Form 10-K and subsequent reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by each company could cause actual results to differ materially from those contemplated. During the discussions, referenced earnings per share will be based on diluted earnings per share, unless otherwise noted. After the presentation, the conference will be open to analysts for questions and answers. In conjunction with this call, WEC has posted on its website a package of detailed financial information at wecenergygroup.com. A replay of our remarks will be available  approximately 2 hours after the conclusion of this call. 
And now it's my pleasure to introduce Mr. Gale Klappa, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of WEC Energy Group.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Colleen, thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us as we review our second quarter results. As I'm sure you know, on June 29, we acquired Integrys in a $9 billion transaction to form WEC Energy Group. We now serve 4.4 million elect
componenttext:
Colleen, thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us as we review our second quarter results. As I'm sure you know, on June 29, we acquired Integrys in a $9 billion transaction to form WEC Energy Group. We now serve 4.4 million electric customers and natural gas customers across 4 Midwestern states. I'll provide you with much more detail on the new company shortly, but first, as always, I'd like to introduce the members of our management team who are here with me today. We have Allen Leverett, President of WEC Energy Group; Pat Keyes, our Chief Financial Officer; Susan Martin, General Counsel; Steve Dickson, Controller; and Scout Lauber, our Treasurer. I'd also like to welcome Beth Stronka, our Senior Vice President of Corporate Communications and Investor Relations. Now many of you know Beth from her work over the past decade or so as one of the more perceptive analysts covering our industry. I wanted to tell you we've forgiven her for that, and we're delighted that she's with us. 
Turning now to the second quarter, pat will review our financial results in detail a bit later on the call, but as you saw from our earnings release this morning, we reported adjusted earnings of $0.59 a share from the second quarter of this year. That compares with adjusted earnings of $0.59 a share from the second quarter of 2014. I should point out that the numbers we're reporting to you today reflect Wisconsin Energy only. Since the acquisition closed on June 29, Integrys earnings were immaterial. 
Taking a very quick look now at the state of the economy, Wisconsin unemployment rate stood at 4.6% June, well below the national average. Deliveries of electricity to our large commercial and industrial customers however, excluding the iron ore mines, fell by 1.4% in the second quarter. And several sectors showed strength, including plastics, prancing and food processing. Also, our small commercial and industrial segment is growing. With electricity use rising by 2.3% over the second quarter of a year ago. In addition, we continue to see an uptick in customer growth across our system. NEw electric service connections are up 8.2% and new natural gas installations were up 4% compared to the same time period last year. 
Now I'd like to spend the next few minutes discussing our plans for the future of the new WEC Energy Group. When we first considered the opportunity to acquire Integrys, we weighted against our 3 important criteria for evaluating any potential acquisition. After considerable due diligence, we found that it met or exceeded all 3 criteria. First, it wouldn't be accretive to earnings per share in the first full calendar year after closing; second, it would be largely credit-neutral; and third, the long-term growth rate would be equal to or greater than Wisconsin Energy's standalone growth rate. We also saw tremendous opportunity in the framework of the new company. WEC Energy Group has the scale, scope, technical depth, geographic region, financial resources to thrive in our consolidating industry. We plan to leverage those strengths to deliver operational and financial benefits to all of our stakeholders, from the customers and communities we serve to the people we employ, to the shareholders who count on us to create value. And with our proven leadership team, we will incorporate best practices across the organization to streamline our operations and reduce costs. 
So what does our new footprint look like? Well as I mentioned, the new company provides electricity and natural gas to 4.4 million customers across 4 states through our customer-facing brands, We Energies, Wisconsin Public Service, Peoples Gas, North Shore Gas, Michigan Gas Utilities and Minnesota Energy Resources. Our company operates in a balanced regulatory environment, with greater jurisdiction on diversity than before the acquisition. And of course, more than 99% of our earnings will come from regulated operations. WEC Energy Group is now the eighth largest natural gas distribution company in the country and one of the 15 largest investor-owned utilities systems in the United States with significant opportunities for growth. Of course, the majority of the earning assets we acquired are here in Wisconsin, a familiar landscape for us. And major infrastructure upgrades are underway now with Wisconsin Public Service in the Northern part of the state. These investment opportunities are similar to those we have pursued over the years on time and on budget at We Energies. We're also in excellent position to take advantage of new customer growth across the region, especially in Wisconsin, Michigan and Minnesota, where propane and oil users are continuing to convert to natural gas.  In addition, as many of you know, Integrys and Wisconsin Energy were the 2 largest owner of American Transmission Company. Today, WEC Energy Group has become a 60% owner of ATC. As you recall, ATC plans to invest between $3.3 billion and $3.9 billion between 2014 and 2023  to bolster electric reliability in our service area. We believe this is a solid plan, and we welcome the opportunity to increase our commitment to the transmission business. 
Now I'd like to briefly discuss some of the conditions we agreed to as we worked our way through the regulatory approvals for the acquisition. In Wisconsin, we committed to an earnings cap for our Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Gas subsidiaries. Starting in 2016 next year, we will share with our customers any earnings in excess of our allowed rate of return. The first 50 basis points of earnings above our authorized return will be split equally between the company and our customers. Then any earnings above that level will go exclusively to customers. This sharing mechanism will be in effect through 2018. We also agreed to develop an integrated resource plan detailing the joint capacity of needs of Wisconsin Energy and Wisconsin Public Service. We expect to file the resource plan with the Wisconsin Commission later this quarter. In Michigan, as we've discussed on previous calls, we expect to pursue the formation of a Michigan-only utility. Our customers in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan will be served by this entity, and we expressed a willingness, if requested, to invest in a new generating plant in the Upper Peninsula and/or purchase power from a new facility. This will allow for the eventual retirement of the Presque Isle power plant. In Illinois, we agreed to return a minimum level of jobs in the state of Illinois for the next 2 years. We also committed to a 2 year base rate freeze and a capital spending floor from 2015 through 2017. In a recent development this past Friday, the Citizens Utility Board, the city of Chicago and the State Attorney General's office, asked the Illinois Commerce Commission to rehear our merger order. These parties are seeking additional conditions, conditions that they previously requested during the year-long approval process. The Illinois Commission now has until August 13 to accept or deny the request. We believe the commission's June 24 decision was correct and is supported by sound principles and by an extensive body of evidence. 
Now let's touch on some of the key financial metrics for the new company. For starters, as you may recall, we issued $1.5 billion of parent company debt to help finance the transaction. The all-in interest cost for the debt is approximately 2.2% annually, an excellent result and clearly lower than we anticipated. So for 2016, we now project our growth in earnings per share to be in the range of 6% to 8%. The 6% to 8% for next year assumes that Wisconsin Energy's standalone achieves earnings of $2.72 a share this year, which is the midpoint of our current 2015 guidance. Just to clarify, we start with the base of $2.72 a share for our standalone earnings this year, and we expect the combined company to grow earnings per share in the 6% to 8% range next year. For the longer term, after 2016, we see earnings per share growth of 5% to 7% annually, driven by operating efficiency, financial discipline and infrastructure investments that the region needs for reliability and for improved environmental performance. We look forward to providing you with additional sales on our capital investment plans at the EEI Finance Conference coming up in November. 
Regarding our dividend policy, in June, the Wisconsin Energy Board of Directors raised the quarterly dividend to forty five and three quarter cents a share, that's an increase of 8.3% over the previous quarterly rate. This is equivalent to an annual rate of $1.83 a share. Going forward, we will target a payout ratio of 65% to 70% of earnings and we expect dividend growth to be in line with growth in earnings per share. 
Switching gears now, I'd like to update you on several of our major construction projects. On the generation side of our business, as you may recall, we're working to add fuel flexibility in our Oak Creek expansion units as part of our ongoing Power of the Future initiative. These units were initially permitted to burn bituminous coal, however, given the current cost differential between bituminous coal and Powder River Basin coal, blending the 2 types of fuel can save our customers between $25 million and $50 million a year depending upon the blend. During extensive testing, we identified operational and equipment related improvements that will be needed to sustain the higher blends of PRB coal on a long-term basis. In May, the Wisconsin Commission approved our request for additional capital spending for plant modifications, expansion of our coal storage capacity and additional coal handling equipment. We already started the work to expand our coal storage capability and the first In-Plant capital improvements are expected to be made on the first unit at Oak Creek, the Oak Creek expansion during a planned outage this September. We plan to upgrade the second unit during the first quarter of 2016. Our share of these investments is targeted at approximately $80 million. 
Next, the conversion of our Valley Power Plant from coal to natural gas. That conversion is now more than 80% complete. This conversion cost are expected to be in the $60 million to $65 million range excluding allowance for funds used during construction. We expect to complete the project on time and on budget before the end of this year. Our Western Wisconsin natural gas expansion project, which will address natural gas reliability concerns in the Western part of the state, is now more than 75% complete and is running on time and better than budget. We expect to complete this new 85-mile natural gas pipeline in the fourth quarter of this year at a cost actually well below the $175 million budget, a budget that again excludes allowance for funds used during construction. 
Looking forward, we continue to see significant investment opportunities in Wisconsin Energy's traditional business as we upgrade our aging distribution networks and focus on delivering the future. Just to remind you, Wisconsin Energy's standalone capital budget calls for spending $3.3 billion to $3.5 billion over the 5-year period 2015 through 2019 and our 10-year standalone capital budget calls for investing between $6.6 billion and $7.2 billion over the period 2015 through 2024. 
Now before I turn the call over to Pat, I'd also like to discuss our plans for the accelerated main replacement program at Peoples Gas in Chicago. Just to refresh your memory, this is one of the largest infrastructure modernization programs in the country. The program calls for the replacement of approximately 2,000 miles of Chicago's aging gas pipeline system over the next 20 years. Some of these pipes, ladies and gentlemen, literally date back to the time of the Civil War. One of our immediate and most important goals is to improve the management and performance of this project. Our first step was to appoint a new senior management team at People's, a new President, a new Vice President for construction, a new operations vice president and a new vice president for customer service. All of them are proven, experienced leaders from the Wisconsin Energy system. Over the past 3 weeks, our team has conducted a thorough evaluation of the accelerated main replacement program. They determine that the best approach is a fresh start. We begun transitioning the management of the project to in-house personnel. Previously the project was managed by an outside contractor. Going forward, we also plan to engage a nationally recognized firm to help conduct an independent bottom-up review of the cost, scope and schedule for the program. This past Monday, we notified the Illinois Commerce Commission of our decisions, and we will incorporate these decisions into a broader transition plan. This broader transition plan will address the recommendations made by Liberty Consulting group in their audit of the program. Liberty audit was completed earlier this year at the request of the Illinois Commerce Commission. I'm confident that the steps we'll taken will ensure that Chicago gets the save, modern natural gas delivery system that they deserve. 
In conclusion, these are exciting times filled with opportunity for our new combined company. We believe we have a very bright future ahead. We will build an enduring enterprise by focusing on the fundamentals, world-class reliability, operating efficiency, financial discipline and exceptional customer care. 
Now for more details on our second quarter performance and our outlook for the remainder of 2015, here's our Chief Financial Officer, Pat Keyes. Pat?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gale. As Gale mentioned, our 2015 second quarter adjusted earnings were $0.59 a share. That's the same as our adjusted earnings for the corresponding quarter in 2014. Costs related to the acquisition of Integrys Energy reduced earnings by $0.24
componenttext:
Thank you, Gale. As Gale mentioned, our 2015 second quarter adjusted earnings were $0.59 a share. That's the same as our adjusted earnings for the corresponding quarter in 2014. Costs related to the acquisition of Integrys Energy reduced earnings by $0.24 per share in the second quarter 2015 and $0.01 per share in the second quarter of 2014. Because of the timing of the acquisition, earnings results this quarter are exclusively from Wisconsin Energy. Going forward, our consolidated earnings will include the operating results of the Integrys Company's. Please note that the balance sheet included in this quarter's earnings package does incorporate the Integrys balance sheet. 
Consistent with past practice, I will discuss operating income for Wisconsin Energy's 2 big business segments and then discuss other income, interest expense and income taxes. Excluding acquisition-related costs, second quarter consolidated operating income was $232.5 million as compared with $245.8 million in 2014. That's a decline of $13.3 million. Starting with the Utility Energy segment, operating income in the second quarter totaled $140.4 million for 2015, a decline of $14.8 million in the second quarter of 2014. On a quarter-over-quarter basis, our earnings were helped by $9.5 million because of the impact to the 2015 rate case and by $3.4 million related to improved fuel recoveries. On the downside, we saw an increase in utility operations and maintenance costs of $18.5 million, primarily driven by increased regulatory amortizations, the timing of projects and certain benefit costs. We estimate that weather reduced our margins by $4.8 million, and we also saw increased depreciation and expense of $4.2 million. Combining these and other factors results in a $14.8 million decline in utility operating income in the second quarter 2015 compared with the same quarter in the prior year. 
Operating income in our Non-utility Energy segment was $93.5 million, which is $1.8 million higher than the prior year. Our corporate and other segment, which includes corporate costs and smaller affiliates, was essentially flat with last year's second quarter. Taking the changes from these segments together, you arrive at the second quarter operating income before acquisition-related costs of $232.5 million, a $13.3 million decline as compared to the second quarter of 2014. In addition, for the second quarter of 2015, we recognize $66.7 million of acquisition-related costs associated with benefit plan agreements, legal and banking fees and other costs. Overall, these costs were in line with our expectations. 
During the second quarter of 2015, earnings from our investment in American Transmission Company totaled $14.3 million, a decline of $3.2 million from the same period in the prior year. As we mentioned in the first quarter, ATC has established reserves in light of recent appeals to the FERC related to authorize returns from regional transmission authorizations. Our earnings reflect Wisconsin Energy's share of ATC's results. Our other income net increased by $18 million. During the second quarter of 2015, we recognized an incremental gain of $15.2 million on the sale of a legacy asset. The purchase of sale of assets is a regular part of our business. In fact, we have real estate development subsidiary and this quarter's sale was part of our financial plan for the year. Our net interest expense increased by $3.1 million primarily because of higher debt levels. Consolidated income tax expense fell by $11.1 million for the quarter. Going forward, WEC Energy Group's annual effective income tax rate, driven by a onetime adjustment related to the acquisition of Integrys, is expected to be between 38% and 39% in 2015. We expect that Wisconsin Energy's standalone effective annual tax rate for 2015 will be between 37% and 38%. Combining all of these items brings you to the adjusted net income of $0.59 per share for the second quarter of 2015. 
During the first 6 months of 2015, our operating cash flows totaled $715.9 million, which is a $5.4 million decrease from the first 6 months of 2014. During 2015, we contributed $100 million to our pension plans. No such contributions were made during 2014. Operating cash flows were helped by improved working capital, for example, lower natural gas prices dropped accounts receivable balances and reduced the cost of gas and storage. Our capital expenditures totaled $356.5 million in the first 6 months of 2015, a $51 million increase compared to 2014. The increase was primarily driven by the increased expenditures related to the Western Gas lateral. 
Our adjusted debt-to-capital ratio as of June 30, 2015 was 50.7%. This ratio reflects the Integrys acquisition, treating half of WEC Energy Group hybrid securities as common equity, which is consistent with past presentations. We continue to use cash to satisfy any shares required for our 401(k) plan, options and other programs. Going forward, we do not expect to issue any additional shares. 
We paid $190.5 million in common dividends in the first 6 months of 2015, that's an increase of $14.5 million over the same period last year. Weather normalized retail deliveries of electricity fell by 1.3% in the second quarter of 2015 as compared to the second quarter of 2014. Actual second quarter deliveries fell by 1.6%. 
Looking now at individual customer segments, we saw weather normalized residential deliveries drop by 3.8%. Actual residential deliveries fell 5%. Across our small commercial and industrial group, whether normal quarterly deliveries rose by 2.4%. Actual deliveries rose by 2.3%. In the Large Commercial Industrial segment, deliveries for the second quarter of 2015 fell by 2.5%. Excluding the iron ore mines, large commercial and industrial deliveries fell by 1.4%. Our year-to-date, weather-normalized retail gas deliveries, excluding the gas used for power generation, were flat compared to the same period in 2014. Our actual gas deliveries, again, excluding the gas used for power generation, were down 7.2% compared to the polar vortex driven gas sales last year. Our overall results for gas and electric sales in the first 6 months of 2015 are slightly behind our expectations for the year. 
Turning now to our earnings forecast, for the remainder of 2015, we will continue to guide based on standalone Wisconsin Energy earnings. As Gale mentioned, our long-term earnings per share growth rate is based upon these standalone earnings. We will, therefore, make the following adjustments to the WEC Energy Group GAAP earnings: Number one, remove the impact of Integrys; number two, remove the impact of acquisition debt. As Gale noted previously, we funded the $1.5 billion cash portion of the acquisition with $1.2 billion of long-term debt and $300 million of commercial paper. This long-term debt included 3, 5 and 10-year tranches. Overall, our debt has an approximate interest cost of 2.2% annually. Number three, move the impact of acquisition and other onetime costs such as banking and legal fees; number four, modify the effective tax rate to remove the impact of the onetime adjustment I just referred to earlier; and, finally, number five, remove the impact of the additional shares issue as part of the acquisition. 
With that, we'll move to our 2015 guidance. We are reaffirming our 2015 standalone adjusted guidance of $2.67 a share to $2.77 a share. We are off to a strong start, but still have 6 months of weather ahead of us. Again, we are reaffirming our standalone adjusted guidance of $2.67 a share to $2.77 a share. And, finally, let's take a look at third quarter guidance. Last year's third quarter adjusted earnings were $0.57 a share, which excludes $0.01 a share related to the acquisition of Integrys. 
Similar to last year, our summer got off to a very slow start this year with temperatures significantly below normal during the first 10 days in July. So taking this July weather into account, we expect our third quarter 2015 adjusted earnings to be in the range of $0.56 to $0.58 a share. That assumes normal weather for the rest of the quarter and excludes any remaining transition-related costs. Once again, our third quarter 2015 adjusted guidance is $0.56 to $0.58 a share. 
And with that, I'll turn things back to Gale.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Pat, thank you very much. I appreciate the detail and clarity. And overall, folks, we're steadily on track and focused on delivering value for our customers and our stockholders.
componenttext: Pat, thank you very much. I appreciate the detail and clarity. And overall, folks, we're steadily on track and focused on delivering value for our customers and our stockholders.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  Your first question comes from the line of Julien Dumoulin-Smith with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  Your first question comes from the line of Julien Dumoulin-Smith with UBS.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Congrats on closing the deal, finally, not too bad. So perhaps, the first question here out of the gate, the 5% to 7% earnings growth rate, when you're thinking about that in the context of this transaction being closed, how are you thinking about the tra
componenttext: Congrats on closing the deal, finally, not too bad. So perhaps, the first question here out of the gate, the 5% to 7% earnings growth rate, when you're thinking about that in the context of this transaction being closed, how are you thinking about the trajectory in '16 and reflecting some of the improvement hopefully in the earned ROEs across the legacy Integrys platform? And perhaps, maybe, could you remind us or refresh our memory of where the earned ROEs stand today? Just first then background if you will.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, be happy to. Let me first start with initial part of your question, how do we think about the trajectory of earnings going forward here now that we've closed the acquisition, as you may have heard me say on the script, given everything we see today
componenttext: Sure, be happy to. Let me first start with initial part of your question, how do we think about the trajectory of earnings going forward here now that we've closed the acquisition, as you may have heard me say on the script, given everything we see today and given the terrific result that we got in terms of the annual interest cost on the parent company debt, we're projecting 2016 to have a growth rate over our standalone 2015 guidance, midpoint of our guidance. So we're projecting 2016 to grow 6% to 8%. And then post 2016, we still see a 5% to 7% growth rate. There are a couple of important underlying assumptions that we're making and that we really feel very good about delivering related to the growth rate. First is that we believe we can, through best practices, through cost reductions, through financial discipline and through on-time and on budget investing in the infrastructure upgrades that are needed, we believe we can move all of the utilities, the former Integrys utilities, at or near the allowed rates of return in Illinois and Michigan and Minnesota and of course WPS Wisconsin. So that's a pretty important underlying assumption. And to your question about where were the allowed rates of return for those utilities, just a reminder that We Energies and Wisconsin Gas have historically earned at or very close to and some years slightly above the allowed rates of return. With that, Pat has the specific numbers on where the other Integrys utilities have been from an ROE standpoint. Pat?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Julian, let's start with the 2 biggest ones., Wisconsin Public Service last year earned just above 10%, and as a reminder, it's authorized was 10 2. So just underneath allowed. The second biggest or the other big one would be People's Gas. That last ye
componenttext: So Julian, let's start with the 2 biggest ones., Wisconsin Public Service last year earned just above 10%, and as a reminder, it's authorized was 10 2. So just underneath allowed. The second biggest or the other big one would be People's Gas. That last year was about 5%, and that's the allowable 9%. And then the other 3 utilities, last year, that will be Northshore, Minnesota and Michigan. Two of the 3 hit, one was beneath, but the year before, the one that mishit and another one did it. So there are more or less may be slightly underneath on average. Probably the simplest way to state that. Does that help?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, that's great. Perhaps getting back to all the more broadly, as you think about '16 to '17, are you earning a full year earn our way, just trying to think about the continued benefit you float that forward, thinking about this 5% to 7% in conju
componenttext: Absolutely, that's great. Perhaps getting back to all the more broadly, as you think about '16 to '17, are you earning a full year earn our way, just trying to think about the continued benefit you float that forward, thinking about this 5% to 7% in conjunction to what is likely, I don't want to put words in your mouth too much, but what is likely still an annualizing factor into that higher level, I would imagine?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure I exactly followed you, but perhaps...
componenttext: I'm not sure I exactly followed you, but perhaps...

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Or are you expecting to earn a full year at or near the ROEs in '16 already, just to be clear about that, or was there an annualizing factor?
componenttext: Or are you expecting to earn a full year at or near the ROEs in '16 already, just to be clear about that, or was there an annualizing factor?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Starting in '16, we're expecting a full year annualized rate of return. And let me help with that one piece because you're probably wondering like how do you go from 5 to 9 at Peoples Gas. But that's a very good question, Julien, I'm glad you asked it . P
componenttext: Starting in '16, we're expecting a full year annualized rate of return. And let me help with that one piece because you're probably wondering like how do you go from 5 to 9 at Peoples Gas. But that's a very good question, Julien, I'm glad you asked it . Peoples Gas did get a resolution of a rate case in January of this year and I believe the allowed increase was $71 million. A lot of that, Julien, was for catch up capital that had already been invested in the infrastructure in Chicago. So the fact that a rate case has been adjudicated and there seemed the benefit of the $71 million increase is helpful on that front. I hope that's helpful to you.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It is indeed. Sorry to belabor it, just one last one in terms of the integrated resource plan, how are you think about that now? Obviously, there were some shifts in the gas generation plants earlier. What is the current expectation vis-à-vis load growth
componenttext: It is indeed. Sorry to belabor it, just one last one in terms of the integrated resource plan, how are you think about that now? Obviously, there were some shifts in the gas generation plants earlier. What is the current expectation vis-à-vis load growth as you stand today as you close the deal? Would you expect to shift back in generation resources meaningfully from what has been discussed through the course of this merger approval?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, let me try the first piece and them I'm going to let Allen give the detail on the integrated resource plan that we'll be filing later this quarter with the Wisconsin Commission. Long story short, there is no change in terms of our long-term demand g
componenttext: Well, let me try the first piece and them I'm going to let Allen give the detail on the integrated resource plan that we'll be filing later this quarter with the Wisconsin Commission. Long story short, there is no change in terms of our long-term demand growth projection. Wisconsin Public Service and our company have pretty similar demand growth projections going forward, roughly 1.5% or 1% a year basically in electricity demand growth. Our belief though when you look at the portfolio generation that the 2 companies have together, our belief is there can be some real synergies there. Allen?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right, and just review for everyone, Julien, you may not know, the Fox Energy Center, which was a plant -- or is a plant that's owned by Wisconsin Public Service, before agreeing to the merger with Wisconsin Energy, they had planned to build a facility ca
componenttext: Right, and just review for everyone, Julien, you may not know, the Fox Energy Center, which was a plant -- or is a plant that's owned by Wisconsin Public Service, before agreeing to the merger with Wisconsin Energy, they had planned to build a facility called Fox 3, which was going to be a natural gas-fired combined cycle unit. And then as Gale mentioned in the script, essentially what the commission said is, well, all right, look at the resources that both Wisconsin Utilities and tell us overall whether that unit is still needed. So Julien, what we've been able to do today, we look to simply what I guess I would call the capacity demand balance between the 2 utilities. If I look solely, we look solely at the capacity demand balance, my expectation would be that you could easily defer Fox unit 3 for a number of years. The analysis that we're doing to go in addition to that capacity demand is a bit of an energy analysis, if you will, if you look at the energy mix of the 2 utilities. My expectation is that it will confirm the capacity demand balance that the unit will be deferred, but that's what we're in the process of doing. And as Gale mentioned in the third quarter, we'll do a formal filing to the Wisconsin Commission along those lines.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Julien, the Fox 3 was estimated to be about a $600 million capital investment, which again, based on our preliminary look, we believe can be deferred.
componenttext: And Julien, the Fox 3 was estimated to be about a $600 million capital investment, which again, based on our preliminary look, we believe can be deferred.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Greg Gordon with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Greg Gordon with Evercore ISI.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I just want to cut to the chase and just make sure I hear you clearly, making all the adjustments you guys laid out, you were very articulate. We should expect you to still be inside the guidance range for Integrys and then we should expect, on a full
componenttext: So I just want to cut to the chase and just make sure I hear you clearly, making all the adjustments you guys laid out, you were very articulate. We should expect you to still be inside the guidance range for Integrys and then we should expect, on a full run rate merger-integrated basis for fiscal year '16 that you'll grow 6% to 8% off that number.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That is correct, you nailed it.
componenttext: That is correct, you nailed it.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, perfect. So you've taken into account everything that's going on, including the onetime impact of this legacy asset sale. You think that everything in the stew pot, that's a number you can hit?
componenttext: Okay, perfect. So you've taken into account everything that's going on, including the onetime impact of this legacy asset sale. You think that everything in the stew pot, that's a number you can hit?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're certainly expecting to do so. But let me mention this onetime thing you mentioned about, the onetime legacy asset sales. We have, for the combined company, like $29 billion of assets. I think every year, Greg, since I've been here, we had some type
componenttext: We're certainly expecting to do so. But let me mention this onetime thing you mentioned about, the onetime legacy asset sales. We have, for the combined company, like $29 billion of assets. I think every year, Greg, since I've been here, we had some type of asset sale. And remember, we also have a real estate subsidiary that develops and sells property. So it's part of our ongoing -- it's just part of what we do, and I would suspect you want us to do this because it's part of maximizing the value of our assets.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I completely understand, just wanted to completely clear on it. My second question is as we think about your cash flow profile, pro forma for the deal is so superior and differentiating factor about your investment thesis relative to almost any other
componenttext: No, I completely understand, just wanted to completely clear on it. My second question is as we think about your cash flow profile, pro forma for the deal is so superior and differentiating factor about your investment thesis relative to almost any other utility given the robust cash flow nature of the Power the Future assets. How should we think about the cash flow deployment priorities of the company as they're built into that 6% to 8% going to 5% to 7% expectation?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of the cash flow priorities, number one through 10 is obviously investing in infrastructure upgrades that are very much needed for customers across the 4 states. And as I mentioned, we will -- at the BEI Fall finance conference we'll give you a l
componenttext: In terms of the cash flow priorities, number one through 10 is obviously investing in infrastructure upgrades that are very much needed for customers across the 4 states. And as I mentioned, we will -- at the BEI Fall finance conference we'll give you a lot more granular detail particularly about our next 3 to 5-year capital investment program. But we see tremendous need and tremendous opportunity for the use of that cash flow to upgrade the electric and natural gas infrastructures at the region. So that's priority #1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 and 10 for the cash flow. And then obviously, we want to maintain the 65% to 70% target for dividend payouts. And if there's any cash left over, well, we've got 3 doors we can go through. One is debt reduction, one would be if we can find legitimately additional investment opportunities for additional infrastructure projects; and then the third would be where we were before, which is a share buyback. But I would hope that -- and really I'm very hopeful that there will be additional investment opportunities that are really needed and that we can put that cash to really good use through infrastructure upgrades.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Just to be clear, are there any specific commitments vis-à-vis the current deferred rating and the discussions you've had with the rating agencies on how you're going to manage the parent debt balance over the next 2 years?
componenttext: Okay, great. Just to be clear, are there any specific commitments vis-à-vis the current deferred rating and the discussions you've had with the rating agencies on how you're going to manage the parent debt balance over the next 2 years?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Pat, I'll let Pat answer that.
componenttext: Pat, I'll let Pat answer that.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: What we talked about, Greg, was the reason we tranched the acquisition debt is that our expectation is that as each tranche matures or comes to its end, we will have sufficient cash flow to be able to not renew that tranch. So in other words, we plan to t
componenttext: What we talked about, Greg, was the reason we tranched the acquisition debt is that our expectation is that as each tranche matures or comes to its end, we will have sufficient cash flow to be able to not renew that tranch. So in other words, we plan to take it out. In addition to that, I might add that we're also looking at what I'm just going to call balance sheet cleanup. We're looking at some of the other debt that's sitting there at the holding company and what opportunities we've got to clean some of that up as well.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Jonathan Arnold of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Jonathan Arnold of Deutsche Bank.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just reiterated the 65% to 70% dividend payout target, Gale, and you obviously wanted a little more than you were committed to post the merger.
componenttext: Just reiterated the 65% to 70% dividend payout target, Gale, and you obviously wanted a little more than you were committed to post the merger.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We thought you'd like that, Jonathan.
componenttext: We thought you'd like that, Jonathan.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: My question is it looks like the payout on the midpoint of the '16 guidance is going to be 63. How soon do you want to get in the range? You typically done December increases. How should we think about that range versus what you've just been discussing ar
componenttext: My question is it looks like the payout on the midpoint of the '16 guidance is going to be 63. How soon do you want to get in the range? You typically done December increases. How should we think about that range versus what you've just been discussing around investment priorities?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a question we will continue to look at between now and the end of the year, but certainly in the relatively near term, we very much want to be at least in the bottom end of the 65% to 70% range.
componenttext: Well, it's a question we will continue to look at between now and the end of the year, but certainly in the relatively near term, we very much want to be at least in the bottom end of the 65% to 70% range.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then what would sort of push you, I guess, broadly, as you look at the earnings outlook, what pushes you to the higher end of that long-term growth rate? Do you have a line of sight of what kinds of things we should be looking for you to announc
componenttext: Okay, and then what would sort of push you, I guess, broadly, as you look at the earnings outlook, what pushes you to the higher end of that long-term growth rate? Do you have a line of sight of what kinds of things we should be looking for you to announce?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Very good question and let me frame the answer, and Pat or Allen would like to add, I would certainly welcome them to do so. Let me frame the answer for you. There's not one single thing that could pop us to the top end of the range on a permanent basis.
componenttext: Very good question and let me frame the answer, and Pat or Allen would like to add, I would certainly welcome them to do so. Let me frame the answer for you. There's not one single thing that could pop us to the top end of the range on a permanent basis. But if you think about our business and where we're headed, there are several factors, the biggest of which would be increased investment opportunity or increased investment requirement that we build on time and on budget and get cost recovery for. That would be the single biggest thing. Then in between, in between rate cases, if you have an economic pickup and a stronger sales growth, there are a number of things that can happen in between rate periods. But the single biggest factor that could drive us to the top end would be additional investment opportunities and infrastructure upgrades. Pat, Allen, anything you'd want to add?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's a couple of things I want to throw in, Jonathan. I think Gale hit the main one, but the other things I would think about was opportunity sales that would help us on the fuel recovery, to the extent that our fleet is called more by MISO and the oth
componenttext: There's a couple of things I want to throw in, Jonathan. I think Gale hit the main one, but the other things I would think about was opportunity sales that would help us on the fuel recovery, to the extent that our fleet is called more by MISO and the other would be hitting -- we talked about our ATC 10-year capital plan and kind of the range it could be in. You're also familiar with our joint venture with the DATC to the extent that some of those projects sit to the top higher end of that back with capital plan, that would also help.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So a lot of it comes down to are there additional investment opportunities as we go forward beyond the plan that will be pretty granular with you, i.e. in fall?
componenttext: So a lot of it comes down to are there additional investment opportunities as we go forward beyond the plan that will be pretty granular with you, i.e. in fall?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I may, just some other point, you talked about having filed with the ICC to tell them you're going to rethink around the main replacement program. Does that include some proposal for how to resolve the ongoing investigation, or a separate issue? Any pe
componenttext: If I may, just some other point, you talked about having filed with the ICC to tell them you're going to rethink around the main replacement program. Does that include some proposal for how to resolve the ongoing investigation, or a separate issue? Any perspective on how we bring that to closure?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's a very good question. Let me be clear about the ongoing dockets. There's one very helpful ongoing docket. Let me back up and explain that. The commission, before we got involved with the potential acquisition, the commission brought in a outside cons
componenttext: It's a very good question. Let me be clear about the ongoing dockets. There's one very helpful ongoing docket. Let me back up and explain that. The commission, before we got involved with the potential acquisition, the commission brought in a outside consulting group by the name of Liberty Consulting. So basically do a review of the management physical, on-the-ground management of the gas main replacement project. Liberty has come back with 95 specific recommendations, most of which are very practical and all of which we agree with. So what the commission has done is they've kept that docket open, and they've asked us by September, early September, to file a transition plan that, in part, lays out how we plan to incorporate those recommendations into our management of the program. So I think a lot of what you're asking about has a schedule and has a definite plan for resolution. But I view the Liberty Consulting report as very helpful and certainly I know the commission has a good bit of faith in the recommendations. The recommendations are very practical. They're recommendations that we would automatically have put in our transition plan anyway. So I think that's the way, I mean, that's the way as we take a step back and relook the entire project, from soup to nuts, from scope to schedule to logistics. We will be incorporating the Liberty audits along the way, and Liberty will also have input along the way. So again, the schedule and a date has been set for us telling the commission how we plan to incorporate the Liberty recommendations. I think that will go a long way in addition to the expertise that we're going to bring to this project. Is.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Michael Lapides from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Michael Lapides from Goldman Sachs.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Gale, congrats on the deal and getting everything closed and rolling out new guidance. One question, though. I know you're starting from the base of kind of a 2 72 midpoint for WEC standalone. I'm just trying to put apples. I'm worried we're comparing app
componenttext: Gale, congrats on the deal and getting everything closed and rolling out new guidance. One question, though. I know you're starting from the base of kind of a 2 72 midpoint for WEC standalone. I'm just trying to put apples. I'm worried we're comparing apples and oranges here because Integrys has a large gas utility presence. That means it generates or delivers a decent amount of its annual earnings in the fourth quarter. And just -- are you thinking that the second half of this year, that Integrys would actually have contributed to EPS or would it have detracted from EPS from the original stand-alone entity? Because a lot will depend on can do what your starting point is and the starting point here is a little confusing.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm glad you asked the question. Let us answer it very directly. First of all, gas, we're picking up a lot of gas delivery companies, and yes, they generally have a very good fourth quarter, they also have a lousy third quarter simply because of lack of g
componenttext: I'm glad you asked the question. Let us answer it very directly. First of all, gas, we're picking up a lot of gas delivery companies, and yes, they generally have a very good fourth quarter, they also have a lousy third quarter simply because of lack of gas demand. But let's step back here. A couple of factors. First of all, the logic, the financial logic for the acquisition was that an acquisition we would want to make, like the Integrys acquisition, would add to our earnings per share growth in the first full calendar year after closing. So that's 2016. So I think the logical starting point is, okay, what would you have done standalone 2015? What would your growth rate standalone have been 2016 and is this better than that? And the answer is yes, it's better than that. So I think if it's making any sense to you, Michael, I think we're starting with the correct starting point. But I'd like to add one other factor, and that is in the second half of this year there will be significant accounting adjustments, a lot of accounting noise around the acquisition as you even saw in our second quarter adjustment. So really the GAAP numbers for Integrys, the Integrys utilities for the second half of '15 are really going to be irrelevant to the long run earnings capability of Integrys utilities going forward. Does that help, Michael?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It helps. Let me ask another follow-on question, and I can catch up with the IR team or Pat off-line. When you think about how far you are in the process about -- of evaluating things like synergy opportunities or other opportunities to benefit, I mean, m
componenttext: It helps. Let me ask another follow-on question, and I can catch up with the IR team or Pat off-line. When you think about how far you are in the process about -- of evaluating things like synergy opportunities or other opportunities to benefit, I mean, merger's only been close for not quite 30 days, right, at 30 days. How early in the process do you think you are? And do you think there is upside to whatever it is you're assuming today in potential long-run, multiyear benefits from the merger?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Very good question, Michael. Let me just say this, we're less than 30 days in. Right now, we're very much on target in terms of our plan for follow on integration. I mean, everybody understands where they report, everyone has budget targets for 2016 and w
componenttext: Very good question, Michael. Let me just say this, we're less than 30 days in. Right now, we're very much on target in terms of our plan for follow on integration. I mean, everybody understands where they report, everyone has budget targets for 2016 and we're in the process of working through every single functional area to determine where we go and what the shape of their organizations look like. So it's a little early to give you much more granular detail, but let me back up. There's nothing that we've seen that would indicate that our earlier thinking and information we've said publicly has nothing to indicate that, that's off track. I would expect that over the 10 years, there will be a minimum of $1 billion of savings for Wisconsin customers alone and a combination of capital and operating costs. And that to me still stands as a good preliminary early estimate. So we'll keep working on it. But right now, I feel very good about where we are. And let me back up to your earlier question again. Remember, the 2 72  that we're talking about as a base for 2015 is Wisconsin Energy's standalone. So we're basically taking out either a positive or negative impact of Integrys utilities from the second half of the year to give you a clean starting point, if you will, that was basically the foundation for the logic of the acquisition.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: Okay, I get it, I get it. Second question, totally different is with all the noise going on with the State of Illinois, can you talk about the legal present for changing conditions once the merger's been actually, you have in order and has been consummated?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, generally in all past cases for the Illinois Commerce Commission to change its order, generally would need to be new facts or some demonstration of an error in the facts that form the basis for the merger order. In this case, none of us see new fact
componenttext: Well, generally in all past cases for the Illinois Commerce Commission to change its order, generally would need to be new facts or some demonstration of an error in the facts that form the basis for the merger order. In this case, none of us see new facts or errors in fact, as a matter of fact, the Attorney General's Office in the city of Chicago, really didn't indicate in any way, shape or form that there were any new facts or there were any facts in error. So again, we believe the commission's decision was very sound, well thought through and supported by significant body of evidence.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and are you guys going to give out any just 2015 consolidated guidance?
componenttext: Okay, and are you guys going to give out any just 2015 consolidated guidance?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, no, I really think it's kind of meaningless, to be honest with you. In the accounting noise around the second half of '15, with the adjustments et cetera, I think it would just make your head swim. To me, the most important thing is are we delivering
componenttext: No, no, I really think it's kind of meaningless, to be honest with you. In the accounting noise around the second half of '15, with the adjustments et cetera, I think it would just make your head swim. To me, the most important thing is are we delivering what we said we would from the acquisition, which is growth over and above our 4% to 6% standalone growth? And what was our base for starting? And that was the 2015 midpoint of $2.72 a share standalone.

componenttext: Okay, well, for Wisconsin Electric, if you recall, we just completed our rate case last December. So our rates with future looking test years are set for 2016 and -- sorry, 2015 and 2016. So under the normal course, the Wisconsin Commission really liking its utilities to file for a case every 2 years. Under the normal course, we would file for Wisconsin Electric in the spring of '16 for rates that would go into effect January 1 of '17. So that's Wisconsin Electric, same thing applies for Wisconsin Gas. For Wisconsin Public Service, they are actually in the midst of a rate case right now, and we would expect a rate case decision, as usual, from the Wisconsin Commission by November or December of this year.

componenttext: Yes, so you're referring to the earnings package, we've got for the quarter rate case net is $9.5 million. And what that represents is going into the rate case last year. When the rates were set effective January 1, the Wisconsin Commission assumed a certain level of SSR earnings, SSR revenues. And what has happened is that the SSR, we reached an agreement with the State of Michigan and those stopped, but in the Wisconsin rate case, we were allowed to have the incremental rapid associated with that. So if you remember last year in the SSR, in the first half of the year, the SSRs were based on the suspension and then later in the year, it went to the return SSRs so the dollar amount was greater in the latter part of there. So the short answer is you will not see this big a benefit last part of the year, but you'll see a little bit of a benefit. Does that make sense?

componenttext: Sure, and I'll ask Steve Dickson, our Controller, and Scott Lauber, our Treasurer, if they have everything to add. Essentially, in any acquisition, we are not immune from this. One of the things that has to be done is purchase price adjustments. Generally you get a year to do that but when you close this early in the year, the SEC would like to bottom down many of the purchase price adjustments by the time of the filing of the 10-K, which should be early, early next year. So one of the major amount of accounting work that has to be done is all the purchase price adjustment work. Then I'm certain there will be some onetime transition-type costs, and there's a whole slew of different types of costs that would be onetime costs that we would incur in the second half of this year. For example, we want to get an improvement in call center responsiveness for a number of the Integrys utilities. There will be some onetime costs to that. Pat tells me that there were software licensing costs that we will incur that will be onetime non-recurring in the second half of this year. We could go on with a list of 30 or 40 of these things that are all transition costs that would be non-recurring. If that gives you a flavor. Steve, would you like to add anything?

componenttext: Well, first of all, I don't think we know the answer to that completely yet. But there is one element, because we have regulated operations in more than 99% of our earnings are coming from regulated operations. But in general terms, when you value regulated assets, it may come over your balance sheet at carrying value, at rate base value if I a making any sense to you. So that actually simplifies a great deal the purchase accounting, however, there are other things that we have to take a hard look at like the value of some of the smaller assets of that Integrys has retained, like the value of a company called Trillium which is the compressed natural gas fueling station company. So there are other assets. I think there's a waste-to-energy plant in Texas that they had. There are several of these assets that we're going to have to take a hard look at and give an appropriate value to. But in terms of major impact on 2016 earnings growth and beyond, Steve, I don't see any, do you?
